item.title: Week 1
item.description: session notes Introducing ourselves; deciding on course logistics; outlining units, sessions, and themes for the semester. üìö Read: Nothing üì∫ Watch: Nothing üéß Listen: Nothing ‚úèÔ∏è Write: Still Nothing ‚ùÄ Related Links on community technology Philly Community Wireless Project Community Tech NY

item.title: Week 10
item.description: Before Class üìö Read: Amaranth Borsuk, The Book, Chapter 1: The Book as Object, pp. 1-60 [only if you have time] Treharne and Willan, Text Technologies, “Writing on Cellulose” and “Writing on Animal Skin,” pp. 60‚Äì77 üì∫ Watch: telegraph operator racing a T9 texting champion interview with Verena Lepper on her digital Egyptology research of Elephantine Island, reconstructing papyrus rolls to be launched 2021, but early version of site here ‚úèÔ∏è Write: an answer to this #response-question: Borsuk defines the book as “a portable data storage and distribution method” whose “changing form is bound up with that of its changing content.

item.title: Week 11
item.description: üöß Visitor: Stephanie Luescher, project manager of Princeton Geniza Project Before Class üìö Read: Borsuk, The Book, Chapter 2: the Book as Content Greetham, David. ‚ÄúA History of Textual Scholarship.‚Äù In The Cambridge Companion to Textual Scholarship, edited by Julia Flanders and Neil Fraistat, 16‚Äì41. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2013. Cohen, Matt. ‚ÄúTime and the Bibliographer: A Meditation on the Spirit of Book Studies.‚Äù Textual Cultures 13, no. 1 (April 15, 2020): 179‚Äì206.

item.title: Week 12
item.description: üöß Before Class üìö Read: TK ‚ùÄ Practicum None. ‚ùÄ Related Links

item.title: Week 2
item.description: session notes ‚Ä¢ slides Overview of the roots of SMS as a technical standard, its current state, and its proposed replacement: the Rich Communication Standard (RCS). Make sure everyone is set up with course platforms, and pair up for the semester’s letter writing. Before Class üìö Read: Scott B. Weingart, “The Route of a Text Message, a Love Story” üéß Listen: “Thank You, Text.” Reset podcast episode (26min) üì∫ Watch: A Brief Look at Texting and the Internet in Film (2014, 5min) ‚úèÔ∏è Write: answers to these #response-questions: A single text message has to pass through many “layers” of translation and transmission.

item.title: Week 3
item.description: session notes ‚Ä¢ slides Visitor: Houman Saberi, Community Tech NY A brief introduction to a number of grassroots, activist organizations working toward digital equity in the U.S. who define themselves as “community technologists.” The key differences between one-to-one messaging, one-to-few group chats, and one-to-many broadcasting. The divide between local ties and global connection. Before Class üìö Read: Greta Byrum, ‚ÄúBuilding the People‚Äôs Internet.‚Äù Urban Omnibus Familiarize yourselves with: Community Technology Collective Teaching Community Technology Handbook, ed.

item.title: Week 4
item.description: session notes Before Class üìö Read: Ahmed, Syed Ishtiaque, Nusrat Jahan Mim, and Steven J. Jackson, ‚ÄúResidual Mobilities: Infrastructural Displacement and Post-Colonial Computing in Bangladesh‚Äù two excerpts from Andr√© Brock, Distributed Blackness: African American Cybercultures (2020) “The Soft Bigotry of Low Information Expectations” pp. 40-41 “‚Ä¶and Mobile Digital Practice” pp. 136-38 üì∫ Watch: Meet the People Building Their Own Internet in Detroit, Vice (12:12) üéß Listen: Interview with Nicol Turner Lee, director of the Center for Technology Innovation at the Brookings Institution, on the FCC’s Broadband podcast (29:22) ‚úèÔ∏è Write: answers to these #response-questions: How do Ahmed et al.

item.title: Week 5
item.description: session notes Visitor: Devren Washington, Movement Alliance Project This class session will be a collaboration with the Philly Community Wireless Project. Before Class üìö Read: Breitbart, Joshua, Naveen Lakshmipathy, and Sascha D. Meinrath. ‚ÄúThe Philadelphia Story: Learning from a Municipal Wireless Pioneer.‚Äù New America Foundation (2007) Introduction, Christina Dunbar-Hester, Low Power to the People: Pirates, Protest, and Politics in FM Radio Activism (MIT Press, 2014) Devren Washington, “Philly School District shouldn‚Äôt have to pay Comcast a dime to get kids online,” The Philadelphia Inquirer (Aug 26, 2020) ‚úèÔ∏è Write: a letter to your classmate answers to these #response-questions: What happened to municipal wireless in the 2000s in Philadelphia, and what is the status of municipal wireless elsewhere today?

item.title: Week 6
item.description: session notes Visitor: J√©r√©mie Lumbroso, Princeton Computer Science (1:30‚Äì2:30) Note: Election Day is a month away. Are you all set up to vote? Please see Princeton’s Vote100 Project. Note: this is the University’s midterm examination week. Before Class üìö Read: David Henkin, The Postal Age: The Emergence of Modern Communications in Nineteenth-Century America (2007). Introduction and Chapter 4. üéß Listen: “The Revolutionary Post”, interview with Winifred Gallagher on 99% Invisible (22:55) ‚úèÔ∏è Write: No response questions for this week.

item.title: Week 7
item.description: Note: due to Fall Recess the preceding Monday and Tuesday, there will be no synchronous meeting this week. We will still check in remotely via the class Slack. Before Class üìö Read: Rachael Scarborough King, Writing to the World: Letters and the Origins of Modern Print Genres (2018). Introduction + Chapter 3. ‚úèÔ∏è Write: a letter to your classmate answers to these #response-questions: Rachael Scarborough King defines a bridge genre as ‚Äúa genre that facilitates change by providing writers and readers with paths across shifting media landscapes.

item.title: Week 8
item.description: session notes Reminder: Election Day is in two weeks. Are you all set up to vote? Also: it’s time to begin setting up meetings with me to discuss your final project. Visitors: Lucas McMahon and Abigail Sargent on “Mapping Medieval Metadata,” a project that maps lead seals used to enclose correspondence and assure the recipient of the genuineness of the contents in the Byzantine Empire. Before Class üìö Read: Joanne McNeil, Lurking: How a Person Became a User (2020) Introduction Chapter 3: Visibility Chapter 4: Sharing Closing: End User Samples of a Byzantine letter and an administrative document, in advance of Lucas and Abigail’s visit.

item.title: Week 9
item.description: A brief introduction to theories of textuality. Why text is never just “information,” even when it’s a CSV or TXT file. Can data be said to have an “author” in the textual sense, even if that data has been unconsciously or unwittingly produced? Before Class üìö Read: Treharne and Willan, Text Technologies: A History, Part I: Conceptual Framework, pp. 1‚Äì33 Roland Barthes, “From Work to Text” (1971) ‚ùÄ
